review_content: Great title, shame about the movie.
While the film is engaging, it feels unwilling to really push its themes into provocative territory.
Writer-director Jamie Babbit's follow-up to But I'm a Cheerleader, while flawed and in need of at least one more script overhaul, is smarter, funnier and more accomplished than its predecessor.
The film's sense of humor is juvenile...
The characters are not complex or memorable enough to linger in the mind much past the closing credits.
trades in platitudes and cliches, for lack of anything distinctive or bold to say

After 75 minutes of carefully establishing the characters and situations, the film comes up with the single most preposterous ending I've ever witnessed in a motion picture, undermining everything that's come before.
Feels like an overwritten fringe festival play, performed outdoors, with a single camera recording it for posterity.

While longtime Treut admirers may miss the gender politics, explicit sex and lesbian SM content of her best known films, the romantic and lush Ghosted offers First Run a good shot at a wider specialty audience.
A clumsily supernatural mystery that strangely uses the fallible density of flesh as its most underscored symbol.
A blandly romantic drama with just the whiff of the otherworldly about it.

Monika Treut (Female Misbehavior) has made a fruitful career out of documenting nonfiction gender studies and LGBT anthropology, but her attempt at exploring such issues in a narrative context is clunky to a fault.
Lesbian and supernatural themes combined to less-than-stellar effect.
Flat visuals, flat script, flat performances: Ghosted is only mildly redeemed by the on-the-ground travelogue footage of Taipei and Hamburg, and I'm being generous.
Clumsily written, mostly in English, with performances to match, the only real mystery surrounding Ghosted is how this soporific bore got made.
An elegant but unsatisfying drama of cross-cultural lesbian love triangles.
Initially intriguing, but tepid romantic drama suffering from an uneven screenplay with stilted dialogue and a distracting, gimmicky ghost story.
A compelling crime saga with supernatural overtones made all the more worthwhile by some spectacular Taipei locales and its celebration of Chinese culture.

[Director] Andreas rescues A Four Letter Word from being merely a raunchy lil' romance by showing how his characters are steeped in a culture of therapy that has filled Americans with endless, compulsive self-analysis and self-doubt.
The semi-earnest A Four Letter Word comes off like an insular gay sitcom, a la Paul Rudnick's Jeffrey, but without the honed verbal wit.
How dismally arch and self-satisfied can a Chelseacore sex comedy get?
There is no denying that Andreas is really trying to say something about the difficulty of real intimacy in a society where easy sex lies in wait on every corner of Manhattan.
Lots of four-letter words get tossed around in Caspar Andreas' naughty sequel to his cheekily titled Slutty Summer, but the scariest one of all is the L word: love.
A Four Letter Word is a surprisingly endearing romantic comedy that explores gay relationships with low-budget verve.
It's always a treat when a movie seems to be exactly the movie that the filmmakers intended to make, and their audience wants to see. It's also a treat when it's a good movie, too.

The film also serves up latte-frothy glimpses of an all-drag bridal shower, an erotic spinning class, and - all of 90 seconds into the proceedings -- naked yoga. Don't forget to bring your wipe-down towel.
The cliches of bad gay filmmaking were lampooned in 2006's Another Gay Movie. Well, here's another gay movie. Things haven't moved an inch.
A gay romantic comedy, witty and charming enough to stand up to any boy-meets-girl date flick in the megaplexes.
Archer's acting is overly arch, but Cory Grant is quite effective as Zeke.
...explores gay life in New York primarily through the eyes of Luke ... who is so busy trying to sparkle that he's made himself into the perfect gay clich.
An incredible love story.
A Secret Love is profound.

A Secret Love still manages to tug at every single heartstring. Pat and Terry had a legitimate love story, one for the ages, and it's one we all should experience, in all its tenderness and fortitude.

At once a misty-eyed romance and a harsh depiction of the practical and emotional challenges of giving up independent living, "A Secret Love" isn't subtle in its Kleenex-clutching tactics... but it's certainly effective.
It's a beautiful thing.
Affecting at times and downright tear-jerking at others, their story is tied to the saga of gay life in America over the past 70-+ years.
Everyone who sees this film will have their own favorite moments.
Like any great romance, A Secret Love is made more piquant by the personality differences between the two women. But they connect with a powerful bond.

A Secret Love stands out by being sweetly understated, at a time when that's especially welcome. It's a deeply felt testament to both the strength of this couple's bond, and the fragility and hard choices that often come at the end of a lifetime.

There is no crying in baseball, but you might just be reduced to a puddle of tears while watching Bolan's film, which finally brings the duo's love out of the shadows and gives it a long-overdue chance to shine freely.
"There's no crying in baseball!" Tom Hanks's grumpy coach said in A League of Their Own, but I was bawling my eyes out watching this film.
Tender without being cloying, naturalistic without seeming contrived, A Secret Love may be the ideal antidote to your least-favorite queer tropes.
It is a compliment that "A Secret Love," which runs under an hour and a half, could stand to be longer, with an expanded portrait of Terry and Pat's early life as a couple.
Docu about women forced to hide relationship for 70 years.
It's enraging that society made them feel they had to hide. But their happiness is the ultimate triumph.
The past in A Secret Love ends up being an anecdotal and colorful backdrop against Terry and [Pat]'s present plot. [Full review in Spanish]
"A Secret Love," with its nostalgic tone flows like a recap of lives. To [Chris] Bolan's credit it's full of both admiration but honesty as well.
If you want a universal treatise on the enduring nature of true love, this is it.
The film is a history lesson, a love story, and a family drama all wrapped up into an 82-minute documentary. And it is beautiful.
Fascinating bittersweet love story documentary on a lesbian relationship.
Amazing but wonderful, for despite feeling like interlopers, audiences will learn much about the family dynamic here...
Beyond the interesting social context, the value of Bolan's film is in the particularities of the story it tells. [Full Review in Spanish]
Bolan gets a very sweet film out of a story where we never doubt, for a second, a happy ending.

This is such a good movie, not just because of its portrait of these two women who had a closeted love affair for so many years... There is [also] an extremely poignant part of the film which is just how difficult it is to deal with elder care.

"A Secret Love" is full of the kind of gentle ribbing and loving chuckles one would expect from any adorable old couple, but it's made all the more poignant by the fact of Pat and Terry's trailblazing personal histories.

A Secret Love is an exquisitely crafted documentary, intimate without ever losing sight of the incredible struggle that these two women and countless other couples went through. This is a personal story on a universal scale.
Enjoyed the history parts more than the current parts but worth watching

To Bolan, we get to see the ladies in their glorious, vibrant youth as career gals in the big city and one cherished piece of footage of the two women frolicking in ridiculously garish cone-shaped hats on the beach.
A Secret Love is in a league of its own documenting the history, love story, and struggles of two pioneering lesbians.
The Chicago-based documentary expertly weaves together LGBTQ history, baseball, and the ups and downs of loving someone for a lifetime.
Enough elements kicking around in it to keep it pretty interesting for its whole running time.
"A Secret Love" weaves the couple's remarkable life story into a sensitive and intimate depiction of the two navigating the realities of growing older together...
So subtle yet so moving, and really one of the best recent movies to hit Netflix...
"A Secret Love" is guaranteed to pull at your heartstrings.
A Secret Love is a refreshingly intimate and sweet romance. Bolan's film is also a welcome celebration of marriage equality that is hard fought and well deserved.

There is nothing but respect and genuine affection here. If anything, the film evokes a sense of admiration and wonder for any couple that can maintain the love and sense of sheer joy for and about each other.
Imagine living with the love of your life for 60+ years & not telling your family? Ryan Murphy produced this Netflix documentary about a lesbian baseball player & her partner.
To those who believe same-sex relationships are inferior or dissimilar to straight ones, they need only watch Secret Love to be otherwise convinced.
A Secret Love beautifully shows that despite society's homophobia that made Pat and Terry feel they had to hide their 70+ year relationship, love ultimately prevailed.
It's a wholesome and lovely film and an undeniable crowd-pleaser well-suited to a streaming release - perhaps even more so than its planned debut at the canceled SXSW festival.
Luminous, simple, amd irresistible. [Full Review in Spanish]
The movie is ultimately a testament to long-lasting true love that can withstand prejudice, family conflicts, and other life challenges that can often tear couples apart.
Forgets to iron out the kinks that make the straight romantic comedies feel like tediously long television sitcoms.
Little more than ninety minutes of bitchy dialogue leading up to a phonily dramatic outburst which purports to tie everything up in laughter and tears.
Very L.A., but in a good way: bright, fast and always informed, with a certain bitterness beneath the glossy surface.
A painfully earnest case of generic romance spiced with queerness.
It makes more sense than the usual slop that gay audiences get stuck watching.
Loaded with smart, sarcastic one-liners and clever potshots at sexless studio movies like In & Out.
A mostly winning, charming, and intelligent entry in the genre.
All four characters are obnoxious, self-absorbed Southern California clichs.
Has enough flashes of whippy humor to pep up what otherwise might have been a routine boy-meets-boy tale.
Another movie about relationships, but not an especially successful, original or involving one.
There isn't much to separate All Over the Guy from the great mass of indie dating comedies.
This is a love story in which all of us will recognize a little bit of ourselves.
It's better than the recent Hit and Runway, and not as good as Jeffrey, which still puts it in the top third.
If you want to watch a gaggle of pretty faux-neurotic people hang out and throw quips, you're probably better off watching Friends.
Thinks it's onto something new by going gay on the static 'boy meets girl, boy loses girl, boy gets girl' formula. It's not.
Badly acted and humorless.
A romantic comedy of wit and substance.
Spirited and reliably funny...but it just feels so workaday, like a sitcom in its fifth season, that nothing much about it stands out.
Bucatinsky and Ruccolo are sufficiently ingratiating to sustain interest and amusement.
It's light and fun, with some peppy dialogue, but it's also sentimental and predictable.
Call it a pleasant near-miss.
Leaves an acrid taste with the viewer who sits through its long and winding tale of tortured courtship.
Plays like a triple-length episode of Friends in which the characters are all in particularly bad moods.
The principals begin to lose any distinction and soon start sounding exactly the same.

If All Over the Guy is any indication of what Hollywood has in store for gay relationships, it looks like gay men and lesbians will be receiving the same shallow treatment as their heterosexual counterparts.
The movie's entertaining for some wickedly funny situations and witticisms.
So it goes, snagging every tripwire of pert banality and ditzy knowingness.
Bucatinsky has presented gay characters every bit as theatrically neurotic and precious as their straight counterparts.
Probably plays better on the stage. On film, the dialogue sometimes seems too writerly, too cute.
A nicely turned and witty screenplay from Bucatinsky.
As one predictable scene follows another, it becomes progressively more likable and more watchable.
Sweet but often tedious.
It may not be totally fresh and original, but All Over the Guy is nearly void of gay stereotypes.
It is not a surprise to learn that Bucatinsky is developing a sitcom based on this film, because it plays like an overly long pilot.

Much of the dialogue is sharp, but All Over is undone by melodrama, an overly familiar story and characters who seem more like stand-up comedians as they rattle off lines like, 'The self-pity bus stops right in front of my building. Get on it.'
A nice little movie.
It says nothing new, but it says it painlessly.
There are no recriminations, and no one is struggling with the issue of "coming out." In fact, being gay is treated as nothing out of the ordinary.
All Over the Guy, while by no means a groundbreaking piece of cinema, is a breezy and fun romantic comedy.
I guess it's a middle of the road romantic comedy... featuring gay men!
Sitcom humor substitutes for wit, and tedious angst supplies the drama.
A funny and warm little film that really deserved more attention than it got.
Better than "The Opposite of Sex", all-round good fun!
This isn't another one of those annoying gay rights movies -- it just wants to have fun.
Move over, American Pie and Road Trip: There's a new sheriff in town, and he's wearing leather chaps.
Mostly likely to appeal to an audience that would enjoy seeing a typical teensploit where the script flips the sexual preferences.
Stephens works much too hard for "Another Gay Movie" to simply land a few scattered titters.
Structured like a comedy, but outfitted with only the most tedious sexual-identity riffs, generic characterizations, and no singular point of view.
Being straight is hard to do in this brief, ponderous mumblecore flick.
The psychologically flat script isn't nearly up to the task of depicting the pleasure within confusion/despair (or vice versa); neither are Rosen's acting chops.
The director's inexperience shows at times...but his writing and acting are fine. Indeed, everyone in the cast is quite good.
A low-key comedy high on charm and credible twentysomething observation.
The title is the cleverest thing about this minor indie portrait of sexual confusion.

Smart without being smart-alecky, Mr. Rosen's writing avoids the aggressive cleverness and gummy politics of many similarly themed movies, focusing instead on realistic dialogue and low-key interaction.

Mildly engaging with an initially intriguing premise and brief moments of wittiness, but ultimately falls flat as a drama. Its bland protagonist, along with a lazy, unimaginative screenplay, leaves you feeling unmoved and underwhelmed.
Enjoyable to watch and worth going to see
The makers of gay-themed films often ignore this rule: Romantic comedy clichs don't become innovative just because the lovers are the same sex.
Better Than Chocolate is warm and loving, if not partcularly wise or nuanced.
Plays like a 'very special episode' of a sitcom. That is, one with explicit nudity and sex.
Anne Wheeler's sexy, funny, poignant film, from a bright script by Peggy Thompson, is a real charmer, with considerable brains.
... for those looking for more, they'll have to tell the filmmaking chefs to put something other than Chocolate on the menu.
Better Than Chocolate depicts the universal humor in the acts of seduction and coupling.
A dreary gay soap opera.
Between Love & Goodbye tells of the ill-fated romance between a pair of East Village transplants with 2 percent body fat, zero personality and even less chemistry.
With a more organic and witty screenplay, Between Love & Goodbye would have been much more engaging rather than often dull, contrived and unmoving.

Helmer-scripter Casper Andreas, whose previous credits (Slutty Summer, A Four Letter Word) adhered firmly and flamboyantly to the comedic, seems to have hit his stride with the operatic excesses of melodrama.
Between Love & Goodbye is a well-made and absorbing cautionary tale. Performances are first-rate, and Jon Fordham's cinematography glows.
lacks professional polish
Beautifully filmed and warmly scored, the movie is a treat for the eyes and ears.
An engaging and generous-spirited romantic comedy.
A big, warm embrace of a picture.
A low-key charmer.
Has all the crowd-pleasing elements moviegoers respond to.
An accomplished heart-tugger, a serious romantic comedy that tackles two dilemmas with honesty and compassion.
I'd call it the gay date movie of the year, but it's so heart-tugging that straight people ought to be in on it, too.
Has a big heart.
Except for its gay characters, Big Eden doesn't deviate from tired romantic comedies about heroes who don't know what's good for them.
It's got solid performances by a strong cast.
A certifiable crowd-pleaser.
Bezucha has drained the movie not only of bigotry but also of dramatic conflict.
It's a sweet movie.
It's a love story in a land of enchantment, all the more affecting because everything looks like this place and this time.
As for "Big Eden," even with its several situation comedy set-ups and leaps of logic, you can't help but be moved by your visit here.
When you lay it on too thick, the audience is distracted by implausibility rather than identifying with the characters.
Yet, for all the film's slow spots, it's impossible not to be moved by Henry and Pike's blossoming romance, thanks especially to Gross and Schweig's charming lead performances.
The dialogue crackles happily and the performances charm.
However well-intentioned it might be, the script is pretty much a collection of cliches.
In his first time out as a writer-director, Mr. Bezucha, formerly in charge of creative design for Polo/Ralph Lauren and Coach, drags his feet, pops corn and sometimes stumbles.
There's something vaguely irresponsible about the movie's navet.
A heart-affecting gay romantic drama that unabashedly celebrates community as the ideal milieu for bringing out the best in people.
Warm and fuzzy.
Bezucha demonstrates a strange genius for dragging out the inevitable.
Genuinely funny and moving, without a single cloying moment.
This fairy tale wraps up the audience without missing the drama of small town politics.
In its gentle, heartwarming, decidedly unrealistic way, it's a refreshing alternative to hipper-than-thou moviemaking.
Big Eden has a simple enough plot, but first-time writer-director Thomas Bezucha has endowed it with the twinkly winsomeness of a fairy tale.
A story about characters who are so extremely closeted that their deepest feelings often remain a secret even to the audience.
It is annoyingly preposterous, corny where it could be comedic, sappy where it could be uplifting.
This may be a date movie with enough quiet charm to appeal to anybody, straight, gay or, like Dean, undecided.
...a funny coming-of-age romantic romp set in the Montana timberwoods, a thousand miles from nowhere.... A sure fire audience pleaser.
Nothing more than a small-town gay love triangle with no antagonist and very little conflict.
Gross doesn't have the spark of a star, and most everyone else seems to hail straight from central casting.
Personally, I found it irresistible -- not great, but definitely irresistible -- and I certainly enjoyed the company of these caring, enlightened people.
Much here is charming, if not exactly plausible.
In an age when self-acceptance and taking a hold of one's destiny is more relevant than ever, Big Eden may be the right inspirational movie for our evolving times.
Surely one of the most genuinely sweet-natured movies around.
Without any true motivation for this love to develop, it's hard to truly believe Bezucha's gay fairy tale.
Echoes the mellow sensibilities of the TV series Northern Exposure.
Other than this gay-friendly gimmick, Bezucha's plot is as hoary as they come.
The characterizations are nifty, but writer/director Thomas Bezucha's stodgy direction holds the story back; there's often a sense that the camera is missing the actors' best work.
Big Eden focuses on relationships and creates a feel good fable that you won't find in ordinary Montana life.
Too concerned with being quirky and endearing and soon runs out of local charm.

Lackluster at 24 frames per second, Writer/Director Thomas Bezucha's debut film, "Big Eden" is another love story about falling in love with the wrong guy, all the while not realizing the right guy is in love with you.
Um belo elenco em uma fantasia aucaradamente otimista que, criada pelo diretor-roteirista Bezucha,  um sonho de respeito de tolerncia. E, por isso mesmo, agradvel de assistir.

What's subversive about it is that it looks just like any other romantic comedy except that some men love other men. Imagine that: social justice, racial harmony, peaceable kingdoms, and a cup of cappuccino at the general store.
Thoroughly engaging, funny, smart and heartfelt without any dull or contrived moments.
Thoroughly silly, occasionally overbearing but ultimately entertaining
The film is by turns clever and cloying.

Happily, writer/lyricist Fred M. Caruso's "divine inspiration" found a largely-talented cast, crew and composer and crafted a show-within-a-show songfest that tackles nearly every pink-triangle issue known to queerdom.
There's a certain boilerplate quality to The Big Gay Musical but it's also a lot of fun...
A clever script and solid acting raises this colourful gay romantic comedy above most films in the genre
Clever anti-evangelical musical comedy.
The beauty of The Birdcage is that its jokes and its message are one and the same. These characters couldn't change themselves if they tried. And only a fool would want them to.
What makes Mike Nichols' version more than just a retread is good casting in the key roles, and a wicked screenplay by Elaine May, who keeps the original story but adds little zingers here and there.
It's a rare event when a remake of a film rivals the greatness of the original.
One of those rare motion pictures with side-splitting laughs where the humor never stays dormant for long.
Basically, the movie's an extended setup for a dinner-table comedy of errors, in which the mismatched relatives confront one another in a nerve-racking test of appearances.
This movie is THE definition of average. Not bad, but not good.
The result is a nearly flavorless 118 minutes punctuated with a few hilarious scenes -- mostly owed to the physical comedy of stage actor Nathan Lane.
Nathan Lane, I would personally like to send you a big, fat kiss of admiration.
This critic admired Robin Williams's performance as well as some of the minor actors, but found the film's depiction of gay people more insulting to them than funny.
The interchanges and conversation are hilarious, and the comedy continues to build until the movie's implausible but humorous end.
A bit of a letdown in some ways, The Birdcage nonetheless features some scene-stealing performances.

The Birdcage is a funny film, with terrific performances by headliners Robin Williams, as an aging gay man, and Gene Hackman and Dianne Wiest as an uptight conservative couple he hosts at a dinner party while trying to act straight.
Far less plastic than most cross-dressing comedies.
An American remake with plenty of new pizazz.
This feel-good family comedy with a twist is based on the 1978 French film La Cage aux Folles.
A glossy miscalculation with Nathan Lane and Robin Williams.
Broad and fairly belabored, but Williams' ceaseless energy, Hackman's dry wit, and Azaria's insanity save the day.
It is not the Broadway classic, but it's ok. Just for fun.
Pretty funny comedy from the days when Williams didn't feel he had to be either A. TOTALLY CHARMING or B. ABSOLUTELY EVIL.
[Not] nearly as funny as it has been made out to be.
Birdcage does a remarkably good job of delivering a movie that puts its own decided spin on the tale.
Broadly funny, with solid performances all around.
If you like to laugh and laugh hard, don't miss this one. It's a genuine hoot.
It doesn't so much champion diversity as celebrate conformity.
Shows no reason why it had to be made again.
The Birdcage is a scream.

If The Birdcage isn't exactly the Mike Nichols-Elaine May movie of our dreams, it does manage to transform what was formerly a campy bit of French fluff into one of the loopiest, most hysterical family-values movies ever made.
What might be a surprise, given the talents involved, is how relentlessly unfunny it is.
It undoubtedly remains a genial crowd pleaser. If the dress fits, wear it.
Colourful, camp, beautifully acted and brimming with gags, Mike Nichols The Birdcage sits comfortably in Hollywood's canon of unchallenging, 'It's OK to be gay' films.
This isn't the supreme masterpiece it might have been, but Nichols's direction is very polished and some of the lines and details are awfully funny.
At its core, it is about human relationships. They're extreme relationships, and they're cross-wired to get an electric reaction, but they're real characters nonetheless.
Robin Williams plays off of a flaming Nathan Lane with delicious understatement and anchors a farce that moves along at a brisk pace-with or without heels.
Campy, comedic romp with lots of profanity.

The Birdcage grossed nearly $200 million worldwide in 1996, and that is significant. Box Office Mojo says it's the highest grossing queer film of all time, though they're not counting Frozen and 300, and they probably should.
The Birdcage is a little film with knee-slapping scenes coupled with thoughtfully acute moments as well.

If you haven't seen Birdcage, check it out on video, or better yet, get gussied up and see it in a theater. Either way, realize and appreciate the very symbolic general public acceptance of the transgender phenomenon (and YOU) this film represents.
While the film occasionally drifts into stereotypes, they are typically rather harmless and Williams and Lane play off of each other perfectly.
The dialogue is sensational, the cast is perfect, the directing is sharp (by celebrated filmmaker Mike Nichols), the music is snazzy, and the film concludes quite cleverly.

Relatively tame retrospective about the relationship of a gay patron of the arts and his famous photographer lover best remembered for graphic, homoerotic snapshots featuring shocking sights like that of a bullwhip in a tight place.
movie_title: Black White + Gray: A Portrait of Sam Wagstaff and Robert Mapplethorpe

review_content: A modest chronicle of an audacious life.
movie_title: Black White + Gray: A Portrait of Sam Wagstaff and Robert Mapplethorpe

review_content: The film itself is staid in comparison to the descriptions of the '70s high life.
movie_title: Black White + Gray: A Portrait of Sam Wagstaff and Robert Mapplethorpe

review_content: Black White & Gray raises provocative questions but can't answer them, or even frame them with total clarity.
movie_title: Black White + Gray: A Portrait of Sam Wagstaff and Robert Mapplethorpe

review_content: Fine, but a little dry.
movie_title: Black White + Gray: A Portrait of Sam Wagstaff and Robert Mapplethorpe

review_content: Draws out the unseen riches that exist within what may otherwise appear typical or commonplace.
movie_title: Black White + Gray: A Portrait of Sam Wagstaff and Robert Mapplethorpe

review_content: Wagstaff was a fascinating figure and deserves the detailed tribute provided here.
movie_title: Black White + Gray: A Portrait of Sam Wagstaff and Robert Mapplethorpe

review_content: A potent exercise in art-world mythography.
movie_title: Black White + Gray: A Portrait of Sam Wagstaff and Robert Mapplethorpe

review_content: The more famous Mapplethorpe is moved aside to give Sam Wagstaff the spotlight. But the best photography in the world steals the show.
movie_title: Black White + Gray: A Portrait of Sam Wagstaff and Robert Mapplethorpe

review_content: This ham-handed interpolation of irrelevant footage is the chief demerit of his movie.
movie_title: Black White + Gray: A Portrait of Sam Wagstaff and Robert Mapplethorpe

review_content: Wagstaff's character accounts for some of the frustration the film induces. Crumb's documentary style accounts for the rest.
movie_title: Black White + Gray: A Portrait of Sam Wagstaff and Robert Mapplethorpe

review_content: The movie makes its main point. Wagstaff was an important, complex, fascinating figure, well worth remembering.
movie_title: Black White + Gray: A Portrait of Sam Wagstaff and Robert Mapplethorpe

review_content: Let's hope this is the springboard for a biopic on the art world's dynamic gay duo - maybe by the time it gets made we'll even have some openly gay actors to play the parts.
movie_title: Black White + Gray: A Portrait of Sam Wagstaff and Robert Mapplethorpe

review_content: Crump's film is a vitally important document in this respect, bringing out Wagstaff's personality and vividly capturing the stories of the people who knew him.
movie_title: Black White + Gray: A Portrait of Sam Wagstaff and Robert Mapplethorpe

review_content: This is a terrific documentary by James Crump about the unsung collector, Wagstaff, and his lopsided relationship with his hungry young lover, Mapplethorpe.
movie_title: Black White + Gray: A Portrait of Sam Wagstaff and Robert Mapplethorpe

review_content: A well made portrait of an intriguing man, presented with a tragic but resounding weight.
movie_title: Black White + Gray: A Portrait of Sam Wagstaff and Robert Mapplethorpe

review_content: Crump's film colourfully depicts Wagstaff's complex inner mindset and rarefied eye for imagery by allowing the stunning prints to linger on the screen.
movie_title: Black White + Gray: A Portrait of Sam Wagstaff and Robert Mapplethorpe

review_content: Good taste is examined in all its implications in James Crump's elegant documentary Black White + Gray: A Portrait of Sam Wagstaff and Robert Mapplethorpe.
movie_title: Black White + Gray: A Portrait of Sam Wagstaff and Robert Mapplethorpe

review_content: Made piecemeal over a number of years and first released in 1983, this 90-minute comic fantasy has lost little of its radical edge.
Interesting as a historical curio but nearly unwatchable as entertainment.
Beautifully made, courageously edited, and swift-moving, this challenging, provocative film is a work that is both humanist and revolutionary.
Born in Flames, while inventive, is also much too diffuse and overcrowded.
Situated at an unspecified future (that seems suspiciously like the present), Lizzie Borden's debut is neither a fatnasy nor an allegory, though it has an interesting feminist idea at its center.

Borden charts the explosive coming together of the women as they forge their own liberation, handling her story with audacity and making even the driest argument crackle with humour, while the more poignant moments burn with a fierce white heat.
The uninitiated should expect more passion than polish.
Lizzie Borden's 16mm independent production, which took some two years to complete, appears to have all the advantages and the disadvantages of a home movie.
This feminist film wins laurels for close attention to detail in a radical filmmaking effort.
It fuses documentary and dramatic sequences into a free-form narrative that exists somewhere between essay film, political manifesto, and exploitation.

Borden's exhilarating collage-like story stages news reports, documentary sequences, and surveillance footage alongside tough action scenes and musical numbers; her violent vision is both ideologically complex and chilling.
The U.S. premiere of the newly restored Born in Flames gives us all an opportunity to reassess this indie classic.
As hackneyed as the phrase may be, Born in Flames is a stark, in-your-face reminder that the more things change, the more they stay the same.
I enjoyed this immensely, largely because of the music and the general ramshackle, hipshot attitude of rebellion.
This is a passionate movie without the self-righteous certainties of so many passionate movies.
Sisterhood becomes powerful, as does their anger, which practically leaps from every frame as "Born in Flames" as it gives a rousing call to action for all women to unite.
A strong cast, formal visual style and cynical voiceover that propels the action help elevate this Seattle-set gay romp from the ranks of the stereotypical.
X dispenses wisdom with the same enthusiasm as the flash-in-the-pan trick-reel demonstrates his professional conquest.
It sentimentalises and moralises at times, but the characters remain nicely complicated right to the end.
raw and real
Boy Culture exhibits a striking density of thought.

A refreshingly realistic, homoerotic adventure featuring recognizable gay characters actually acting gay, not behaving in some sanitized fashion intended to appeal to straight audiences. The gay version of Jungle Fever!
Boy Culture dares to speak on the gay experience without the need for affectation, and it's a rewarding and often superb viewing experience.

A film made by people just smart enough to acknowledge that the tropes of modern queer filmmaking have been reduced to cliché, but who themselves lack the courage to push beyond tried-and-true box-office formulas.
Shrewder than you'd think and not half as dumb as it looks.
As a character, X is rather reticent and buttoned-up. If he'd stayed that way as a narrator, a rather nice film would have been even better.
It is buoyed by some incisive acting and writing and anchored by a standout portrayal from Bauchau, a versatile veteran of international cinema.
A guilty pleasure. Just enjoy the view and don't expect cerebral stimulation.
In a role that could easily have slipped into bitchy smugness, [actor] Magyar gives the character a self-deprecating charm that's enormously appealing.
The overall effect is merely narcotic.
Direction and performances are not up to the task of making this convincing or moving.
Brocka leaps into the small circle of leading queer filmmakers of our time, sculpting an unpredictable romance that is complex, sophisticated and thoughtful.
A drab, contrived drama in which men have sex and then complain about it to us.
Brocka's direction keeps things moving, and the performances he draws from Magyar, Stephens and indie-film veteran Bauchau are always up to speed.
These self-involved studs manage to make ready, anonymous sex look rather dull.
You know something's amiss in a movie when an omniscient narrator blathers the entire way through it.

BOY CULTURE is a well-made, engrossing and well acted comedy-drama. [The main character] X can easily reside alongside Jon Voight's Joe Buck in MIDNIGHT COWBOY as one of the screen's more memorable hustlers.
Despite cliches, film does click.
Benefits from some assured helming by Q. Allan Brocka and strong performances.

Seattle locales, some spry lines and tiny soundings of depth still leave us in the conceptual grip of 'love' as a system of endless bartering and vanity, with impulsive copulation treated as consecration. Oh, boy.
It's a better-than-average gay relationship film, largely because neither plot mechanics nor the same old camp intrude much.

Audiences outside gay cinema will, frankly, probably find it too callow to emotionally invest in. However, for those who do see it, they will likely be surprised, and entertained, by its arch insights and near-camp bearing.

Boy Culture is an undemanding but sufficiently engaging serving of smut and sentiment. As such, it reclaims territory that queer cinema has largely ceded to TV shows like Queer as Folk, The L Word and Six Feet Under.
A traditional vapid romantic comedy.
Actor Derek Magyar makes an impressive feature debut in this somber video drama about a financially savvy but emotionally distant male escort.
If anything about this scenario sounds remotely interesting, it's not.
The terrible trio whine their way to a happy ending that is wholly undeserved.
Has got to represent yet another low for the gay indie, New York Style.
Unless you want to see a former Superman playing a gay guy, The Broken Hearts Club has disappointingly little to offer.

It's almost the point of The Broken Hearts Club that it doesn't crank up the emotion. It insists on the ordinariness of its characters, on their everyday problems, on the relaxed and chatty ways they pass their time.
An amalgamation of dozens of old television sitcoms.
What we have here is no less than the 30th anniversary rerelease of the infamous 70s gay-angst drama, Boys in the Band.
Light but consistently entertaining ensemble comedy. Dean Cain is a riot.
This gay heart-warmer may have a fuzzy, sitcom-ish appeal for some.
may actually show its strength by being average
In short, audiences may be buying a ticket to see Dean Cain kiss another guy, but there's a lot more to The Broken Hearts Club than that lovely sight.
It's fun, but its desperate desire to be liked eventually wears you out.
One of the best independently financed bank-robbery flicks since Bottle Rocket, despite the complete absence of any actual bank robberies.
Rather staid and uninteresting road trip.
Remarkable debut feature.
Refreshingly, this tale of stone butch blues is rarely treatise-like; sexuality never devolves into agitprop.
By Hook or by Crook is, like its principal characters, a bit messy and maladroit but not without a certain charm.
An appealing, if decidedly unconventional, buddy picture.
It quickly becomes tiresome and clich-ridden -- not to mention depressing and pointless.
The title ... must be alluding to the possibility that large parts of the movie are begged, borrowed, and stolen from early Gus Van Sant.
Three weeks may be the ostensible time frame for the plot, but sitting through this nauseatingly whimsical and pointless confection feels like a downright eternity.
A weirdly compelling train wreck of a film that's as raw around the edges as its protagonists.
It's a buddy movie, albeit the queerest buddy movie ever that makes Midnight Cowboy look tame in comparison.
A ragged but endearing buddy movie.
[By Hook or by Crook] has a topical resonance rare even in recent releases.
The Celluloid Closet is a first-rate work of cinematic criticism, tracing the ways in which, despite cultural disapproval, gay images, ideas, and implications have slipped into the medium.
The filmmakers have gathered together a staggering array of the moving images that the book could only show in still form or verbal description.
Top-notch entertainment, not only because it's enjoyable, but because it argues its case with an effectiveness that would impress even a top-notch, homophobic attorney.

Even if The Celluloid Closet ... isn't quite the most perfectly political piece of filmmaking that you'd expect (or hoped) it would be, it's still a pretty convincing argument and, what's more, likably entertaining.
No less than a primer in the power of movies to redefine human nature and behavior.
Although the film will clearly appeal to homosexuals and to film buffs, I believe that anyone seeing this documentary will find it an absolutely engrossing and fascinating movie.

It's interesting to see how gay and lesbian themes began to be treated openly in films, but it's fascinating to see how -- earlier -- those themes were used subtextually in films that make no overt reference to the real subject.
A remarkable look at the treatment of gays and lesbians in cinema.
Makes it clear Hollywood wanted it both ways: It benefitted from the richness that gays added to films, but didn't want to acknowledge their sexuality.
this documentary makes it plain that Hollywood has hardly been a leader in social causes,
Like a scrapbook of movie memorabilia from some of the greatest films ever made, it's a welcome look back at the ever-changing times of the world around us.

Celebrity interviewees and glossy graphics further turn this into a colorful overview with the popular appeal of a "That's Entertainment!" and with an even more interestingly gay agenda than the history of Hollywood musical comedy.
Entertaining but ultimately shallow.
Rock Hudson was gay? Who knew?
An engaging documentary touching on Hollywood's on screen treatment of homosexuality.
It's engrossing, brings a healthy sense of humor to the discussion, and enlightening without being bludgeoning.

Instead of an angry diatribe against Hollywood, the film shrewdly opts for a wity, often campy commentary by gay figures (Gore Vidal), directors (Wyler) and actors (Tom Hanks) who shed light on the context in which these films were made and viewed.
A witty, touching study of Hollywood's (mostly on screen) treatment of homosexuality.
An immensely entertaining, galloping reflection on screen perceptions of lesbians and gay men, from the humorous to the heinous to the heartening.
How ironic that a movie about the dangers of the closet would so confine one's freedom of interpretation.
Opening the door of the celluloid closet reveals a shifting kaleidoscope that underlines just how influential, for good or bad, the movies can be.
Lively and absorbing.
This intelligent, fascinating film - based on the book by Vito Russo - is well worth a watch and is stuffed full of clips and contributions from stars, directors, screenwriters and academics.

"The Celluloid Closet" goes all the way back to the birth of cinema, to an experimental Thomas Edison short of two men dancing, to trace the odd, funny, sad and disgraceful history of homosexual iconography on film.
A fascinating account of how Hollywood has dealt with homosexuals and homosexuality through its history.
